												Painkiller Overdose was released in 2007, three years after release of original Painkiller. It's a single-player "old-school" FPS with Deathmatch multiplayer. And a sequel or stand-alone second expansion pack for Painkiller. It started out as a mod, being made by fans effort, and then was made official.So, technical side of thing. Game is supposed to still work on newest systems. It even supports wide-screen resolutions, even though HUD will be stretched. So it all should be cool.Oh, and game is as bugged as it always was. It will crash on you. Randomly. Or in some cases always in same situations. Like, when you are trying to equip tarot card after beating some level and having some amount of gold. Nope, no idea what causes it, but you will relaunch game few times while beating it for sure.AND loooooong level loading times. I have no idea what changed, but these take few times more than in original Painkiller. It's painful enough to make you wish that this game had either "rewind time" or more console-like checkpoint system. Or just anything that doesn't require you to reload level after death. Like, lower difficulty to die less to. Yea, it's bad even today.Oh. And don't be surprised if ragdoll of defeated demon decides to kick you up to moon. Ragdolls don't feel done properly here.As for multiplayer? Well, it was mostly competive one like Deathmatch. And well, I don't think it was played like Painkiller was. And with GameSpy shut down, you can still connect, but Internet Browser will not work. So it will be hard to find servers with people. Community is probably dead there.Story follow Belial, child of demon and angel, who proved to be too powerful and chaotic-neutral in war between Heaven and Hell. Who was then imprisoned by Cerberus from Hell side, while being overseen by Samael from Heaven side. And now, after Lucifer death, he was freed and out for revenge. While travelling absolutely random locations.So, it adds whole new campaign made of 16 levels or so. On theory it's great. It has great variety, as you will travel between such locations as fantasy land, space station, egypt, riot in modern city, zombie town and it has such interesting and amazing stages as Demon Farm and B-Film Studios. And borefest of green radiation like Power Plant, yes. And not only that, but each level is filled with at least some unique monsters, scarabs at Desert or living cardboards of B-Film monsters.And yet all this random variety gives this game a cartoonish feel. What Hell? What Nightmare? Travelling around globe and time and dimension, it seems. It doesn't help that most monsters seem to be take off the wall, stereotype, futher contributing to this feel. Not that it's a bad thing.It also lost some feel due to different music, which is weaker. There are some interesting parts of fight music for some levels, but it's all errr "bland epic", so to say. Ambient part is weak too. Just nothing truly memoriable, so good bye awesome metal too.It'a also nice how few enemies, including old ones, gained a special death animations. Even though they are so slow at times, you may not notice that enemy is technically dead.But hey, the game has 8 weapons. Freaking eight. And knowing how seven of them has two alternative fire modes, which use serapate unqiue ammo, and seeing how weapon switching is instant, that pretty much means that you got 17 different fire modes that you have to remember and think about! It pretty much creates a "having bunch of toys" feeling. Sure, you have many different ways to kill demons. It's probably fun for most. But you see, since functionality and effectiveness pretty much always overlaps with few of them, you actually will be lost what to use. They all do fine job and nothing is absolutely more effective in each situation, so you don't really have to think on which weapon to choose. Which is one of the things that keeps old FPS interesting, having to decide on weapon use. Well, aside from running out from ammo for some.You will spend time scrolling around weapons to find the one with some ammo left. That's quite a lot. And game doesn't always provide you with enough ammo. Sometimes there is too much, other times it tries to give you only for some weapons and sometimes there is just plain crisis. Power Plant level comes to mind. It shows that this game started as a mod, as sometimes it feels amateurish with difficulty jump.And I don't understand the use of acid flame thrower.And yes, what I said, there is difficulty jumps. Some encounters will prove to be harder than others. And it's not always at the end of the levels. Like, it uses same Monks enemies in Ragnarog level. But this time, they didn't place any laying corpses around for them to be busy throwing, instead they will keep telekinetically shove player, doing hitscan damage on him from few miles away.And then you got easy-easy bosses. Who got weak points. At least they aren't the worst of Painkiller.And then there is a hero who tries to be baadass and Duke Nukem like, throwing one-liners regulary. Same ones. Not too clever. So get ready to hear "taste like chicken" a lot. He only rarely drops something more interesting like "did that demon just revive another one?".And sadly, despite having big themes variety, it just ends up being monotonous. Original game was avoiding that, it had few surprises. It had more specialized weapons, more varied monsters. It wasn't too chaotic in themes. It just had flow. While in Overdose it just feels like you kill things and then repeat, not really mattering what kills and how you kill. Or at least not enough mattering. I don't really understand, on theory it's awesome, but on practise it's not so fun. Levels also feel sometimes on dragged side. Weaker music don't help.And I wish weapons didn't gib everything just because.Getting Tarot Cards is still not so fun, by the way. Just like in original game.So, Overdose isn't a bad game. It's not good FPS either. It has variety in level themes, but it's too repetitive in gameplay. It's the kind of game that you will have fun with, but will have to force yourself with "I should beat this game fully because I want to beat games", otherwise you will abandon it in a half way.

												The game has some beautiful level aesthetics and monster designs, which is almost a shame, because everything about the actual gameplay is so bad that these great assets are just wasted.Even on normal difficulty, you'll find yourself running out of ammo for not just your favorite weapon, but for all half dozen separate weapons extremely frequently - including secondary ammo!  You are simply not given enough bullets to work with, turning what should be tense or exciting fights against dozens of enemies into pure frustration as you run around looking for what few ammo pickups have been hidden across the large expanses.While being forced to make the best of it with your infinite ammo starter weapon, you'll have to slog your way through countless bullet spongey enemies, many of which spawn adjacent to you, teleport or use incredibly hard to see projectiles.  Unfortunately, your character, who seems defined primarily by his ability to recycle the same three or four unpleasantly dull one liners throughout the whole game, is not nearly tanky enough to deal with these battles very well.Finally, even the weapons are merely recycled clones of Painkiller Black's arsenal, making them not so much new as modded.The not too shabby presentation of this game is let down by almost everything else about it, but especially by the total lack of respect for the player given in the design of enemy encounters.  Mixing and matching the strict ammo rationing of a Silent Hill game with the relentless hordes of a Serious Sam makes for a poor FPS experience, whether you're oldschool or new school.

												AUDIO:Various styles ranging from heavy metal, carnival music, and spooky haunted house style stuff that fits the level that you are in. There is a lot of variety here and it's nice to have so many different songs to kill baddies to. Belial is a one-liner spewing jerk throughout the game. It's nice to hear him comment at the beginning of every level because it can be humorous and it gives him personality, but good lord he never shuts up while you're playing. I LOVE THE TASTE OF EVIL SOULS IN THE MORNING.VISUALS:Like the original Painkiller, Overdose offers a plethora of different environments to gib enemies in. A snowy viking village, the battlefields of the American Civil War, and a movie studio production lot to name a few. Every level is drastically different in theme from the previous one, so it offers a good incentive to keep going and see just how diverse this game can get. The enemies change every level to match the setting, so you won't really run into them multiple times except in a level near the end. PLAYABLILITY:This game does have a tendency to get hair-rippingly difficult at times. Mainly when they pit you against a horde of enemies that have some sort of quirk that melts your health to nothing in no time flat in a claustrophobic environment. Like the Riot level. Those flamethrower enemies are ridiculous. Aside from that little balancing issue, it is the same frantic and fast paced gameplay as the original Painkiller. DELIVERY:The gameplay is very similar to the Serious Sam line of games, just set to a darker tone. There is a pretty large variety of weapons to choose from; some a bit more useful than others. If you've played the original Painkiller, they're basically just reskins of those weapons. Each level offers you a challenge to complete in order to unlock Cards which can be used to grant you special powers, such as faster speed or changing how much damage you do. Overdose is the type of game that focuses more on its gameplay than its story, with maybe 4 total cutscenes in the whole game that sum up the story to that point. Easy to understand and doesn't take itself very seriously.SUMMARY: So the big question is: Should you play this game? My answer to you is that you should go decide if you want to play Painkiller: Black Edition first. If you play through that and need more Painkiller to satiate your appetite, then give this a whirl. it's not as balanced or polished as Black Edition is, but it is still fun to give a playthrough. If you didn't like Black Edition, than you are sure as hell not going to like this one. It is a game with flaws, but it still pulls through in the end. Final Score: 7/10

												If you're looking for a challenging, fast paced old school FPS with cool weapons, tonnes of enemies to kill and a great art design, Painkiller Overdose is the game for you. There are lots of collectables to find along the way, rewarding players for exploring the maps. This keeps the pacing of the gameplay steady and allows you to take a few deep breaths after murdering countless demons and trust me, you'll need to. Enemy ai isn't the best but they will team up to ko you. Some enemies have tricks up their sleeve to be careful of. Plus there are many environmental hazards to look out for such as lava, swinging maces etc. There are also tarot cards to collect which give you special powers when activated once per level. These cards are permenant and you can unlock them by satisfying certain conditions at the end of a level. The weapons are cooler than ever, you will get some really creative ones to try as well as your conventional shotgun. Levels are well designed and have lots of hidden ammo/secrets and tonnes of enemies to kill.Another thing to note is that the protagonist, Belial who just happeneds to be a demon/angel hybrid is a far more entertaining character than Daniel and has the tendancy to deliver one liners every now and again, particularly after consuming his favourite food, evil souls and he makes this very clear.The only downsides are the framerate drop which often occurs when enemies spawn into the map. This can be annoying and can break you away from the action sometimes. Plus the enemy ai can be pretty stupid when it comes to pathing, something you'll find in most painkiller titles, enemies will lose track of you easily. Also be careful with your saves. always delete the ones you don't need as the game has the tendancy to corrupt data and crash the game when too many sames are accumilated. One level in particular, Animal Farm has an awful save glitch which can corrupt data randomly on that level, basically you're required to beat it all in one sitting with no deaths as i guarrentee 80% of the time, the checkpoint autosaves will get corrupted, if you want to get the tarot card on that level, i strongly reccommend playing it on daydream to save yourself the frustration of dying and having to return to the beginning of the level.Other than that, this game is worth picking up if you are looking for a cheap old school shooter with a twist. Pick up the black edition too.

												To start: I used to add a much longer header to these reviews, but I've opted to keep it on my Backloggery page for the sake of brevity. Also, I had written a review for Painkiller: Black Edition, but Steam Reviews were glitchy and saying I hadn't played the game for more than five minutes (which I had played MUCH more than), so I just uploaded that review to PasteBin. Here's the last bit of the URL; you should know what to do with it: yyxEHtWBGameplay: Since this game is an expansion, I'll be writing the gameplay section assuming you've read the prior review or know what Painkiller is all about, as things really haven't changed too terribly much. However, saying that nothing has changed is a disservice, honestly. There are a lot of "carry-over" weapons, such as the Shotgun/Freeze Ray and the Rocket Launcher/Chaingun, but there are a lot of weapons that were either tweaked to make them more fun or were changed for the most part, such as the ever-unloved Stakegun being changed to a toxic waste launcher and the crossbow sniper having the alt-fire of the Stakegun. You've also got grenades which pretty much for me became the "I'm out of rockets, so here's another source of boom." The titular Painkiller has been changed to a Razor Cube, but it's still functionally the same.As far as the enemies go, there's still quite the variety. When the game introduced as much stuff as it did in Chapter 1, I was afraid that it was gonna spend itself too quickly. Fortunately, this wasn't the case. Most of these enemies are pretty fun to fight, but some of them are just plain obnoxious. Pretty much par for the course for the Painkiller series, though. The boss fights aren't nearly as cool as the boss fights from the original, and DEFINITELY not as cool as Battle Out of Hell's boss. In fact, the first boss is pretty much a throwaway one, as it is literally just a really big version of an enemy from the first level. The second one is pretty neat, but the third one isn't really all that good. Again, it's like the Battle Out of Hell boss in that you've gotta wait to be able to attack it, but unlike in BOoH, you can't influence the boss becoming vulnerable. It's just a matter of waiting around for the boss to make itself vulnerable.Somebody made the comparison to Rise of the Triad (presumably ROTT '95 and not ROTT '13, 'cuz ROTT '13 owned) in the review section, and I really think that's the most apt comparison you can make. Chapter 1 in terms of stage design is pretty great, Chapter 2 is somewhat less great but still pretty alright, Chapter 3 becomes the point where you're saying, "I just want this game to be over with." If Chapter 1 were released shareware, I'd say go get that. However, I still overall had a pretty good time with this game, even if my enjoyment declined over the span of the game for various reasons. If you're a fan of the original Painkiller and you just want more, I'd say you'd be alright with getting this. 7/10.Story: Basically, Belial be belligerant toward Samael (and yes, that was a forced alliteration). Fortunately, the cutscenes don't crash the game this time around. However, I skipped them due to lack of interest as the story really isn't very good. Honestly, these games shouldn't even have a story. Just make it a bunch of levels. Since the game did try and have a story, though, I'll talk about it. As for the dialogue, it gets REALLY tiresome. Basically, Belial tries to be Duke Nukem and make "witty" one liners all the time. To paraphrase one of Claptrap's lines from Poker Night 2, "SHUT THE FSCK UP, BELIAL! Sheesh, and people say I'm annoying!" 5/10.Graphics: Fortunately, the art design is still as fantastic as the original's. Enemies look really awesome, the stages are usually pretty huge, and the game overall just looks like every metal video ever. Just the way it should be. Fortunately, the weird screen shake glitch didn't happen like it did in the original. I still turned it off, as it really was just more annoying than anything else. As for the technical side of things, this game does require a bit of juice to get going, but as long as you've got what the recommended card is on the Steam page, you should be just fine. I didn't really experience any graphical glitches, although there was some portions of 2-5 that caused a considerable amount of lag for no reason whatsoever. This was only a two or three minute stretch of the game, so I'd consider it inconsequential. Overall, this game still manages to hold the high standard that one would expect from Painkiller's graphical capabilities. It's definitely a game that'll still look pretty awesome in five or ten years time. 5/5.Sound: This game has a real big issue with peak limiting. Like seriously, it got so bad at times that I had to turn off the game audio, as it was hurting my ears. I don't know why, though. 3-5 was the biggest culprit of this issue, so be warned. Anyways, the soundtrack is a bit... different this time around. Rather than going SO METAL, the composer decided to branch out a little bit. In fact, there really isn't any metal tracks in the game at all, save for the one from the repeat level from BOoH (oh yeah, did I mention this game lifts a level from BOoH?). While the change is nice, it runs the risk of being forgettable and not necessarily conducive to what's going on in the game. And to be honest, I really can't remember a single song from this game, whereas in the original, the songs may have gotten tired after a while, but there's a lot of memorable riffs in there. It's not a soundtrack I'd get for myself. As for the voice acting, again the main issue is the dialogue the one VA has to work with, so it's a bit tricky for me to pass judgement on the quality of the VAs. However, what I can pass judgement on are the audio engine and the soundtrack, which are both honestly pretty disappointing. 2/5.Overall scores are: 7/5/5/2; cumulative score of 6.3/10. It's not something I'd see myself replaying too terribly often, but I don't feel bad about spending my time playing it, either. If you like Painkiller, you might like this. You've probably already got the Painkiller Pack that goes on sale quite often, so you might as well dive in. It's better than a lot of modern shooters, that's for sure.

												I had a great time with Painkiller Overdose and I still play it to improve my scores and try higher difficulties.I have tried Black Edition and I agree it's the better version, but this game has a quicker more arcade feel to it that I enjoy.For those unfamiliar with this series, Painkiller is a fast paced arena style FPS (first person shooter), and I would compare it to Quake 3 in terms of controls and jumping.There are 17 maps in 3 chapters (or so) with a couple bosses and tons of unique and creative enemies. You have a lot of weapons to use, and some hidden secrets and pickups in the maps. You may encounter problems hosting if you are using a router.Overdose is cheaper than Black Edition,  don't pass this one up, it's very fun.

												Steam doesn't record my playtime for Painkiller Black Edition, so consider this both a review of that and this expansion.Awful enemy design. Compare it to games like Serious Sam or Duke Nukem, who both had enemies that were distinctly different from each other and easily displayed what sort of attacks they had. Instead, the obsession with having unique enemies for practically every level leads to boring and indistinct variations of "brown and grey spoopy thing" that often have attacks that aren't readily apparent. Also, most of the enemies with guns are hitscan. Combine this with level design that often borderlines on claustrophobic and you've got a game that falls flat on its face as a horde shooter.The main game is slightly better than the expansion; some of the levels are actually nicely designed, and you aren't being peppered with the same 5 one-liners every 2 minutes, but it still suffers from the awful enemy design. If you do get any Painkiller game, get Black Edition and stop there.

												More varied than the first game, Overdose almost entirely uses original enemies and doesn't endlessly recycle enemy design like the other expansions Resurrection, Redemption and Recurring Evil seem to do. There are many lovely vistas to see: the levels take you to a Japanese village, nuclear plant, farm, Pompeii, battle during American Civil War and other authentic locations. Most weapons, but not all, are comparable, if not identical in functionality to their Painkiller counterparts, but the weapon models are carefully recreated. Ammo is scarcer than in the original, I felt that this design choice encourages creativity by forcing the player to use all weapons. Graphics are noticeably upgraded over PK1, but unfortunately the frame rate fluctuates, in particular on the Haunted Valley level most likely due to heavy particle effect usage.Farm stage is the standout, featuring some truly bizarre, twisted design also found in the Killing Floor series.
